results.title: Static generation
results.creator_credit: Mobil Oil Australia and Monash University
results.brief_description:
This 1980 film demonstrates the importance of using a static wire when transferring petrol and other flammable liquids. The instructional film uses an animation to explain how electric charges build up on the surface of the petrol as it is being transferred, and if there is no static wire to earth the charges, an explosion will occur. The film then shows footage of petrol tankers being filled, while earthed with a static wire, and small test runs of petrol being transferred from bucket to bucket, and the static charge that results. It also includes footage of a large explosion, indicating the severity of not following the procedure.

Produced by Mobil Oil Australia in conjunction with the Department of Chemical Engineering, Monash University.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Kampuchea after Pol Pot
results.creator_credit: Australian Freedom From Hunger Campaign, Mary Leggett and Mark Stiles
results.brief_description: Shows the Kampuchean people’s will to survive and the progress they have made in rebuilding their shattered lives. Traces the operations of the Freedom from Hunger Campaign and the obstacles placed in the way by international politics. Narrated by Don Dunstan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Freedom From Hunger Campaign, Mary Leggett and Mark Stiles

holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Game girls: Heathens
results.brief_description: This tape contains two short documentaries about the culture surrounding football. “Game girls” (directed by Miriam Cannell), follows the role of women in Australian football and the often silent but loudly significant role they have played. Rated PG. “Heathens” (directed by Megan Spencer), confirms that there are really passionate and vitriolic supporters out there as director Megan Spencer follows St Kilda supporters with names like Thommo and Chook. Watch out for the language, which is alot more colourful than the red white and black. Rated R, for reasons which become very apparent from the first five seconds.

holdings.name: VHS; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: Not just a number
results.creator_credit: Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, Rob Richardson and Shalagh McCarthy
results.brief_description: A three part documentary examining industrial democracy in Australia: 1) Job redesign. Demonstrates how employees exercise decision-making, responsibility and initiative in their private lives and contracts with the usual workplace situation where most decisions are made by management. 2) Better managers. Shows a factory owned and operated by the workers providing a working example of successful worker participation and industrial democracy. 3) Is it a con? Examines unsuccessful industrial democracy initiatives where only the semblance of power has been transferred to the workers.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, Rob Richardson and Shalagh McCarthy

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various moments in the Anderson family, including kids’ birthday parties, beach holidays and First Communion at the church. There is some great footage of fashion in the 1960s, particularly beach wear.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a birthday party, kids eating cake and wearing paper hats
00:01:08:00 a boy blowing vigorously on a party horn
00:02:00:00 birthday boy receiving his gift, a Tommy Thunder toy machine gun
00:02:33:00 girl with fake vampire teeth
00:03:01:00 people sunbaking on the beach
00:04:03:00 the three boys learning to swim
00:05:47:00 snow or hail on the streets of Ballarat, driving through the storm
00:06:12:00 kids on toy bikes and pushing a dog in a pram
00:07:45:00 rows of children in matching outfits at church
00:08:25:00 learning to ride a bike
00:10:30:00 First Communion at church with all the girls in white dresses and veils
00:11:57:00 an older couple walking down the street
00:13:00:00 boys in party hats
00:13:40:00 birthday cakes and frog in a pond (chocolate frog in jelly)
00:14:45:00 more relaxed sunbaking on the beach
00:15:16:00 the three boys in matching bathers (swimwear)
00:15:47:00 picnic under a large red beach umbrella
00:16:42:00 boy in yellow terry towelling hat enjoying a can of Fanta
00:18:55:00 group of kids exploring on the beach and throwing food to seagulls
00:21:03:00 on the slide at local playground

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows John and Marie on a holiday in Tasmania. They spend time in Hobart, visit New Norfolk and Port Arthur, and finally Launceston.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title cards ‘Holiday in Tasmania’, ‘Produced and Photographed by John R. Anderson’
00:01:30:00 Wrest Point Hotel in Sandy Bay, Hobart
00:02:15:00 views from Mount Wellington, Hobart
00:04:07:00 Franklin Square, Hobart
00:05:00:00 plants and flowers on the road
00:06:10:00 the Bush Hotel in New Norfolk, one of the oldest pubs in Australia
00:07:45:00 driving through the snow
00:09:20:00 visiting the ruins at Port Arthur
00:10:45:00 aerial view of city streets in Hobart including the General Post Office
00:13:47:00 Cataract Gorge Reserve in Launceston
00:15:40:00 city street in Launceston
00:15:55:00 a visit to Entally Historic Home
00:16:28:00 Marie looking stylish with luggage and camera tripod in front of a bus
00:17:25:00 on the boat

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 29]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

In this film, we see the Anderson family on holidays, firstly with the kids at a horse riding school and then at a beach house, swimming, playing cricket and fishing.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:08:00 the kids learning to ride horses at a riding school
00:03:57:00 kids on the beach searching for crabs
00:04:10:00 a bucket of crabs
00:05:39:00 one of the boys on a paddle board
00:07:48:00 the girls playing cricket in the backyard
00:09:27:00 one of the boys dancing to a wireless on the patio
00:09:49:00 cooking steaks on a BBQ
00:11:28:00 the kids with a freshly caught fish
00:13:34:00 de-scaling and gutting the fish

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 27]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows John and Marie’s honeymoon on Hayman Island in Queensland. They travel up through New South Wales and Queensland, passing through Tamworth, Surfers Paradise and Brisbane, before taking a seaplane to the Whitsundays. The film has excellent footage of summer holidays with friends, fishing, playing tennis, swimming, and exploring the island and resorts.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 title cards ‘Hayman Island’, ‘Produced and Photographed by John R. Anderson’
00:00:18:00 1950s cars driving down a busy main street
00:01:19:00 kids playing and people swimming at a local pool
00:01:54:00 Tamworth town centre featuring the Tudor Hotel
00:02:05:00 driving down a street lined with jacaranda trees
00:03:04:00 banana plants
00:03:34:00 the exterior of the Café Cathay in Surfers Paradise
00:03:50:00 Brisbane City Hall
00:04:29:00 sign for ‘The Oasis: Queensland’s Most Beautiful Garden’
00:05:00:00 boys on a diving board above a beautiful pool
00:05:45:00 catching a seaplane to the Whitsundays with some beautiful footage over the water
00:09:35:00 two women looking out over the coastline from a cliff
00:10:15:00 at the resort, by the pool with striped umbrellas and deckchairs
00:11:10:00 group of friends in holiday attire
00:11:31:00 man carrying a large fish, very pleased with his catch
00:11:58:00 holidaymakers lined up for a group shot
00:13:00:00 time at the beach
00:14:38:00 searching for oysters
00:14:50:00 another catch – a swordfish
00:15:08:00 game of tennis in bathers
00:16:40:00 on a boat, exploring the island
00:18:50:00 Melbourne Bitter Ale and Cairns Bitter Ale beer bottles
00:19:55:00 shells at a shell shop
00:21:28:00 cooking a picnic on an open fire at the beach
00:22:00:00 new people arriving on a boat
00:22:57:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [John Anderson Home Movies: Reel 36]
results.brief_description:
John Robert (Jack) Anderson (1924–1993) was a film distributor, cinema owner and photographer as well as an enthusiastic filmmaker in and around Ballarat in Victoria. Jack developed an interest in film very early at cinema shows and gained his first film experience while serving in WWII, photographing wartime conditions and aircraft involved in the defence of Australia’s north, including the aftermath of the Darwin bombing raid.

It was whilst working in photographic studios that Jack met his future wife, business partner and fellow film enthusiast Marie Bourke. Starting out by hiring films and showing them around regional Victoria, Jack and Marie established cinemas such as the Astor Cinema in Ararat, Bell Post Hill Drive-In in Geelong and the Southern and Northern Drive-Ins and Vegas 70 Cinema in Ballarat. In the 1970s, the Anderson family acquired and restored the Regent Theatre in Ballarat which would then become the first multiplex in regional Victoria.

Along the way, Jack filmed his family and friends activities and outings, horse racing, Ballarat street scenes, motorcycle scrambling and travel scenes on the road – an unusual and wonderful look at life in regional Victoria during the 1940s to the 1960s.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

This film shows various recreational activities in the life of the Anderson family, including water skiing, riding speed boats on a lake, a trip to the snow, visiting the Royal Melbourne Show, birthday parties, swimming at a local pool, and a Christmas morning.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 skimming stones at the river
00:01:15:00 picnic lunch, eating sausages in bread
00:03:55:00 an ANSETT plane at a country airport
00:07:40:00 water skiing on a large lake
00:08:25:00 groups of people on the shores of the lake
00:09:46:00 man with binoculars
00:10:24:00 kids eating ice creams
00:11:02:00 sign for ‘Water Ski Spectacular: The Fastest Show on Water’
00:11:18:00 the three boys at a table set with birthday cake and party cups
00:15:04:00 on a speedboat on the lake
00:18:47:00 another birthday party with balloons and cake
00:18:56:00 double-layer sponge cake on a rotating tray (lazy Susan)
00:21:47:00 blowing out the candles on the cake
00:22:33:00 trip to the snow
00:23:18:00 kids learning to ski
00:25:00:00 siblings in matching outfits holding hands at the Royal Show
00:25:12:00 Showbags stall
00:25:17:00 on the Racing Speedboats ride
00:26:15:00 the Kiddies Ferris Wheel
00:26:25:00 the Merry-Go-Round with the older girls holding the boys on
00:27:08:00 on the Speed Car ride
00:27:57:00 girl with fairy floss in front of the fairy floss stand and then thoroughly enjoying it
00:28:13:00 sign for ‘Delicious Flavoured Milk’
00:29:29:00 the Mad Mouse ride
00:30:00:00 Christmas morning with a pile of presents under the tree and the kids in their pyjamas
00:31:25:00 in the backyard riding new bikes and race car toys
00:33:15:00 playing at the local pool with an inflatable boat
00:37:34:00 a large group of kids lined up for a bike race
00:38:37:00 group of girls on the trampoline
00:39:04:00 cake with a ballerina and ‘Happy Birthday to Denise’ written on top
00:39:28:00 blowing party horns
